name: Year Walk
description: In the old days man tried to catch a glimpse of the future in the strangest of ways.Experience the ancient Swedish phenomena of year walking through a different kind of first person adventure that blurs the line between two and three dimensions, as well as reality and the supernatural.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP Processor: 2 GHz Memory: 1 GB RAM Graphics: Pixel Shader 2.0, 256 MB Storage: 1100 MB available space
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 7 (or later) Processor: 3 GHz Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: Pixel Shader 2.0, 1GB Storage: 1100 MB available space

reviews.review_text: Year Walk is one of those rare bits of media that lingers in your mind long after you've finished it. It makes you feel like a part of you is missing after you've finished it and, like a junkie, you become desperate for more. Don't let the 'ending' fool you. There's more. Find the Journal. Open the box. It's not too late.   You know what to do.

this game, oh man.  heads up, i played this on ipad almost a year ago and it still holds up really well even on pc  its super creepy and has a vibe not many puzzle games have. the best way i can describe it is that it feels like a popup book rendition of a super creepy swedish folklore version of myst. everything feels dream-like but you soon start seeing that not everything is as it appears.  +great art +great soundtrack +captures the feeling of being lost in the woods +lore is polished really well +puzzles are outstanding and mostly nonlinear, and without spoiling you have to dig pretty deep to solve some of the more arcane puzzles -relatively short for a pc game  ... its almost midnight.

Year Walk is a game that I first purchased about a month after it's release here on Steam, over two years ago. I mainly just wanted a quick horror fix, and what I got was a lot more. This game focuses on the very obscure ancient Swedish tradition of Årsgång, or Year Walking. After playing this game, I was awestruck by not only the way the story was presented, but also by the amazing visuals, and how even though there was certainly horror elements in the game, I felt completely comfortable.   Upon completing this game, I felt like I needed to know more about this tradition that was Årsgång. This feeling sent me on a two year journey through Swedish sources and 20 year old dead internet forums that helped me conclude a whole blog and thesis on this subject. Never has a game compelled me so strongly to find out more, and to know all I can possibly know, and in April of this year, I had done it. I had found out all there was to know about this once obscure tradition that now found itself as common knowledge.  This is why I am asking everybody who could be reading this to BUY THIS GAME. You will be intrigued, terrified, curious, excited, mystified, and much more over this 2 or so hour journey, maybe three if you read the excellent encyclopedia. I've played this game 5 times now at different speeds and settings, just to make sure I found every little thing in this game. Now that I have, I must say it was completely worth it, and I'm sure I'll be going back to it again soon. Some people may find this game boring, and I understand that, it's not necessarily for everybody out there, but please just try it. This game is $6.00 (£4.10), when it should easily go for twice that price. if I had to give this game some sort of overall rating, it must be a 10/10. I feel ridiculous giving a rating out to a game that has changed the way I see things so much but I feel it's justified. Just play it.

If you're into creepy mythologic stories, (this one touches swedish/scandinavian folklore) you should give it a go. The game is rather short, but it does its job. I had a jump-scare at some point, but the rest is just chills down the spine, 'oh my god did stuff like this really happen', kind of game. I loved it, the only SHORTcoming being its length.  The artwork is wonderful and so is the music. 10/10 no regrets!

Year Walk is a great game that is well worth it's price. Though the game is short, it is packed full of content and you'll be entertained from start to finish. The game mechanics are simple and the puzzles are challenging but not irritatingly so.  Where this game really shines is the incredible atmosphere. Few games that I have played have really drawn me into their world the way that this one has. The scenery and the music work together in a way that make you truly feel the game as you play it. I honestly felt that I was wandering through a supernatural forest seeking answers to questions that only the spirits knew. Don't even get me started on how eerily creepy the game was, especially since when I first started playing I hadn't been aware that it was a horror game. Your second time through the game only adds to this as you learn A LOT about the events of the game through a second individual's eyes.   If you're looking for an atmospheric, creepy puzzle game with a deep storyline, look no further. Year Walk is worth a playthrough!
Year Walk does to swedish folklore what Kentucky Route Zero did to American folklore.

WOW! 10/10 I absolutely loved this game. Very gripping!  Pros: 1. Art style is amazing. 2. Good atmosphere 3. Very creepy 4. Puzzles are well done 5. Interactive (if you played you would know what I mean) 6. Multiple play throughs are encouraged with a tease ending  Cons (none of which are deal breakers in any way): 1. Short 2. Jump scares (I find these lame in anything, others may enjoy it) although one could argue it added to the atmosphere and feel of the game.  Great work here! A masterpiece! I will definitely be playing this again.

year walk is one of those games that you download at 1 am on a saturday and for some reason feel really empty and sad when you finish. P.S don't skip the credits theres a good 15-30 more minutes of story and puzzles after it.

Year Walk features a delightful set of puzzles weaved seamlessly within a well-conceived and aesthetically pleasing dark world story. If you take your time and really read into the details of the surrounding the 19th Century Swedish Folklore, you are in for a treat.  It’s deceptively short, pay close attention to the end credits for the “true experience”.  This game deserves your time. Even at full price.

Solid attempt to reveal da truth. Uncovers Facebook and CERN's plot to control Dialga and Palkia. CERN's large Hadron Collider and Facebook's Oculus Rift are unreliable means of time travel. I found many bananas embedded in my walls. My microwave is broken. The Illuminati are the observers.  Would recommend to those who are new to time travel.

A creative endeavour that very much deserves to be played. It requires you to put some effort in like taking notes and it has a great atmosphere. It's fun to read the lore and let your mind drift while playing. A most worthy break which doesn't outstay it's welcome.

Year Walk is definitely an interesting game, maybe less so 'game' but huge emphasis on interesting. I would call this a visual story (not to be confused with a visual novel) and while most games are obviously 'visual stories', I'll try to give a reason as to why I call it that. I'll start with the gameplay as that will help me get my point across.   Your character (never given a name) is put into this beautiful snowy landscape. The only movements you can make are to walk left and right, or forwards and backwards on paths. You have a cursor so you can click on objects here and there, but there aren't a ton of things to interact with. Hence, why I say this is more of a visual story. While you do have control, I feel more like you're just watching through their eyes.  Onto the gameplay/setting. The term 'Year Walk' (Årsgång) refers to a Swedish ritual that was believed to be done by people from the medieval times to the 19th century. The Year Walk was done on either Christmas Eve, or New Years. The idea is that you lock yourself in your house, void of light, no eating, drinking, or interacting with others. After which of 24 hours, the year walker is tasked with heading to their church in order to have a vision of the coming years future. There, they will have to pass the tests of supernatural creatures in order to be granted that vision.  The premise alone is very intriguing, and I knew nothing of it while diving into this game. Let me say this, I played through Year Walk in one sitting. Now, it only took me about 2.5 hours, but that time alone was very gripping and I couldn't wait to progress further along. The atmoshpere of the game is mind blowing. Play this with headphones on and in a dark room for full immersion. The game is also genuinely terrifying through it's use of the lore. Added that the soundtrack beautiful and the art is amazingly well put together, you've crafted a very serene yet eerie world that can totally draw you in and make you lose sight of things.  While I would love to tell you much more about this game, I really need to leave it up to you to discover what it holds. It's not terribly hard, puzzle wise, but there are some here and there. Also, in game, if you'd like to read up more, they provide an encyclopedia that provides some descriptions of what you'll encounter. I've also heard you need to play it more than once to really get the full picture. So, I hope you will play this as I highly recommend it. It's something that will stay with you long after it's over.  P.S. Don't worry about the box. Yet.
First game of the genre I played and I was overwhelmed by it! Great art and music, interesting folklore, mysterious and unexpected puzzles and a tragic yet beautiful story.

Year Walk is one of the most interesting and unique experiences I have had in gaming for a very long time. It's a first person adventure horror game based around the little known Swedish folklore of the 'year walk', a ritual where individuals go without food and drink all day and then wander the woods at midnight, hoping to gain visions of the future but also potentially encountering dangerous supernatural beings. As such, the setting and story are fantastic and really draw you into the game. The great soundtrack, creepy sound effects, and unique visual style that looks like a mix between a pop-up book and a silent film help to enhance the setting even further and make this game a very emotional experience. While playing Year Walk, I truly felt the sensation of being all alone in a dark forest. In this way, the game was simultaneously comforting and terrifying in a way that I can't quite explain. Another enjoyable aspect of the game is that it essentially drops you into an open world and leaves you to explore and solve puzzles on your own, much like Myst or The Witness.  Overall, I highly recommend Year Walk. It's an experience not easily forgotten and best played on a dark snowy evening with a good set of headphones.

I've played this before on the iPhone and just had to snap it up from Steam in order to get the full experience on a bigger screen. Year Walk is a hauntingly beautiful game that is well worth the money and well worth the time.
This game will mess you up in the head... but in a good way
Very original with the way you move through the game. You quickly get used to it. Interesting and fun missions to do. All in all an awesome game if you're into a little weird and spooky stuff.

Truly one of a kind game, one of the few games that actually got me to do as much research as I could to see if Arsgang or Year Walk was a real thing, going as far as thinking of doing the tradition for fun myself.  Great atmosphere, few scarier parts, visually very appealing game 10/10

This game is a lovely point-and-click puzzle horror game. For $5 it's more than worth it, and playing it again was very nostalgic. The developers went for a choice that favors symbolism over action, so if that isn't your thing, don't pick this up. It's very artsy, and there are a bunch of secrets hidden after you beat it for the first time, so it has a decent amount of replay value.  10/10 Flawless
This game turned out to be absolutely flawless, albeit tricky at times, incredibly beautiful.

A beautiful game with a unique and mysterious atmosphere. It involves puzzles, which aren't particularly hard if you pay attention to your surroundings, yet they do feel rewarding.  ATTENTION! WAIT FOR THE FULL CREDITS ROLL AT THE END BEFORE QUITTING THE GAME.
Amazing story, loved the gameplay. New way of playing first-person. Too short though x)
Best game to give you chills and make you cry, but, it is worth knowing you get a second chance to make things right.

Now this....THIS is a game. Year Walk harkens back to the days of HTML/flash games that were exclusivly in browser, like the Bionicle one that used to be on the LEGO website. While starkly simple, YW capitvates its player with a completley unique sountrack and quite obscure historical and mythical items. I can't possibly explain the story line, but the premise is that you, in your crazy swede mindset, decided to follow the traditional avenue of the 'Year Walk'; a ceremony of sorts where the person in question isolates themself for a whole day in a dark house without food, water or exposure to anything whatsoever, then ventures into the remote woods at nightfall to encounter beasts, magic and possibly see the future.  Before you ask, yes, this was a real thing that people did. I'm proud to be swedish, but good grief are my people wierd.  Anyway, I would recommend this for PC, not for a phone though - I can forsee some dificulties trying to navigate if you would have to use your fingers instead of a mouse.
LOVE the game's look, aestetics, and puzzles. also another indy game with awesome visuals.
Mind-Blowing Point & Click
Minimalistic. Powerful. Simple. Profoundly Clever. Alluring. Chilling.  Year Walk.  10/10

Satisfying little puzzle/adventure game that encourages repeat play-throughs to flesh out the narrative. If you like scribbling down game notes and easy cryptography, you'll enjoy this. Takes about an hour your first time through.
You walk for a whole year. If you buy this game in 2014, you won't finish it until 2015. Great value for money.

This game is superb. I have played it on iOS as well as the PC versions. The puzzles are pretty intuitive, and the navigation and environments are really interesting, but what really gets you is the lore. Using either the companion application for an iOS device or the built in one on the PC makes the game a much fuller experience. It helps make the bridge between the player and the lore behind the symbols easier to cross, and you get that feeling of 'OHHHHHHHH, NOW I get it!'. Don't play it alone, or do, but be warned; the jump scares will scare you and the game itself will send shivers down your spine.

Get it on sale if you are really interested. I could barely make it 10 minutes into this. The only horror I was able to experience was fighting the games interface to move around and explore things. A game about walking shouldn't feel this far removed from the concept of walking.

Quiet, beautiful, haunting, unnerving. Albeit short, it leaves enough of an impact to bring me back to wander in the cold, desolate woods once again. Any fan of subtle horror, mythology/folklore, or both- this game is a must-play.

The best word to describe Year Walk is probably 'genial'. If you are into scandinavian culture stop reading this and buy the game right now. If you are not... still buy the game, because even the achievements expand the mystery and the story. An amazing folklore experience.

Year Walk is that game that people love because of the context, scenarios and different puzzles. But in my opinion this game is not enjoyable at all... Hard puzzles that doesn't make sense, tips that doesn't help you within the game and finally the story is not that great... Mix old folk pagan tales with an emotional background and you have the story of the game, yes it seems great but IN the game it DOESN'T. There is no explanation what so ever for some mysteries and to finally add that it is waaay to short.

Well, certainly it's a game with story elements, but I don't really get what's going on here. I didn't find it to be engaging at all, I had no reason to seek out the storyline. There seem to be a lot of games in this genre, which I can only really describe as artistic adventure, that don't have enough narrative in them to really grab you and make you want to take the ride.  As for me, I either want a game that launches me into a story with a reason to care about the fate of the PC, thus giving me a reason to do more stuff, or an immersive enough experience that I can become the PC and am motivated to go off and explore. For me, this game had neither - I didn't feel as if I had any agency, and didn't care if the story was advanced at all.  Maybe it'll be your thing, but I was lost in the woods.
It is just a beautiful game. Regretting no second I invested into it. Play until you see 'The End'.

This is the closest you will come to the feeling of a real-life treasure hunt.  Year walk seems to have the incredible ability to constantly surprise you by breaking all the rules about how things work. I had more than a few 'ah ha!' moments with this game when I solved puzzles or got hints in ways I never expected.  The end is just the begining. They are watching.
Amazing visuals and sound effects, compact with a great story One of my favourite games of all time   10/10   s(^-^)-b
More jumpscares than a Pewdiepie video

Year Walk isn't really all that much a game but more of an interactive story. A story that you cannot alter no matter what you do. You only move around on the map, do a few puzzles, and the story progresses. The sad thing about the puzzles are that it is impossible to solve them without looking at the hints and still it's extremely difficult. Chances are you'll be utilizing an online walkthrough to guide you through a story that you have no control over. It also has ZERO replayability as it's only appeal is the unfolding of the story. Like a book, once you've read it, you're done with it.  The only pluses that Year Walk has are that it's relatively cheap and that the story is interesting. If you like a good mystery story with psychologically creepy imagery then this is for you. If you're looking for a puzzle game solely because you want to solve puzzles then you'll be disappointed.  I'm recommending this title but barely. Had it been a few dollars more I would have said no.

For those of you who like to try a bit more of a trippy horror, get this game. Music is fantastic and the visuals are just superb. Its a different way of playing a game and at first I thought the whole side scrolling thing was weird. At first you may think its boring, but once you find your way you can't stop playing.  Buy this game when it goes on sale, its worth to have in that library of yours.
Awful. Don't believe the hype.

I bought this game because I like solving mysteries, point-and-click games, and eerie/odd things. I like fairy tales, folklore, fables and ghost stories. I thought I would really like this game based on the video and description. In truth, I love the art style and music of this game. The map is cool and not hard to figure out.   For starters, it's kind of annoying not knowing what to do without using the clues. I play a lot of puzzle games, but I very rarely use hints or clues. I had to use them every time with this game. I would have liked this game despite this aspect though.  I feel like this game was misrepresented in the description and video/screenshots. The first 5 minutes were okay. I just wandered around, figured out the map, viewed the encyclopedia. Most people have said that there are just a few times that things jump out at you or are horrifying. So far almost everything after that first 5 minutes happening in the game is VERY scary/horror to me... not just eerie/creepy. It isn't just a few times. All I've seen/heard are    screaming, scary images, bloody scenery, and dead babies.    There should be more emphasis on the horror aspect in the video and description.  Unfortunatly, I just can't finish this game. It's too scary, graphic, and bloody. As a warning, don't play this game if you are    pregnant or planning to have kids any time soon.

like the name of the game says it feels a year to walk, on the first level. i'm realy realy confused what this game is about. you stupidly click around and hopes that you find the way, after that you reach sometimes the next checkpoint and the hunt for the right path begans again.  graphic makes i bleed, cruel sound, crap leveldesign, absolut NO gameplay! This is game is all you need for a present to your worst enemy!
A short and sweet horror puzzle experience with a setting and feel all its own.
A scary puzzle game with super creepy jump scares. Love it so far and love the style of the game. Good game for horror fans that like a deep story as well.

Short, but you won't find anything quite like it. Not extreme horror, but the creepiness of these old myths had shivers running down my body the whole time. Extremely interesting, and definitely worth it.
This game is magnificent. Beautiful and haunting.

Year Walk is a short, creepy adventure that is 2 parts adventure game and 1 part interactive fiction.   Inspired by the Swedish folk tradition of Arsgang, Year Walk sets you in the shoes of someone who dares to undertake this strange journey.  The art and simple controls, as well as the sensation that you are watching an old film complete with tears and dust on the print, put you into a realm where anything could happen. It is not without some quality jump scares and unsettling imagery. There is a bit of Lovecraftian horror dwelling within Year Walk.  The puzzles fit into the world well, although while manipulating them you can tell the game was conceived for tablets. It should not diminish any enjoyment, however. They are clever enough to make the player feel smart upon completing them.   And the less you know going into it, all the better. Year Walk is worth it for fans of interactive fiction games and creepy short stories.
Amazing game with just as amazing graphics. Would play again at least 3 more times
Good, short, two play through worthy game.
This was the best game i've ever play in my entire life.  10/10 year walk again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again

Beautiful art and nice scary atmosphere. If you like puzzle games and mythology, you probably enjoy this game. At first, the story could be a little confused but it keeps your attention pretty well.   Oh, one more thing: this game is available to share with your friends and family :)
I wished this game was longer, but it was a really great game. There were a few times that I was caught off guard. I would recommend this game to anyone that enjoys puzzles and a creepy environment.
It's very short, so buy it on sale, but I will not soon forget this game. There are still dark things lurking the corners of the world that man was not meant to see or know.

An incredible and beautiful experience. Rather short, but I got it on sale so I don't mind. The artstyle is gorgeous and the story is compelling. Traversing the forest is creepy without being terrifying and there's only one jump scare that I can remember.  Very good, interesting game. Wish there were more like it!

This game is short, but sweet. The art and music are phenominal.   I think the main thing that helped me solve puzzles was realizing the game was made for a touchscreen-mouse clicks and whatnot suddenly make WAY more sense. You want to focus on music, and reaize that although the PC version holds up well...problem solving is way easier once you know it was made for a touchscreen.   I did wish it was longer. I struggle to complete games normally and found this short.
Played my first Year Walk, and god its gorgeous and horrifying at the same time. Gonna do some more walks, the re playability its rly good.

Really interesting game! I wished there were more of this kind. IT's intriguing and has really lovely artworks. Though I have to admit I jumped here and there in a scene - eerie, but not blood-freezing. Really good - and walk at least twice ;)

This is a beautifully constructed game.  The dark, supernatural atmosphere is fully immersive, with haunting music and sound effects, a creepy unlockable journal, traditional Scandinavian monsters, and a few jump scares that add to the surreal horror. A warning, though: If you are at all squeamish about blood or death, you will have a hard time playing this.   The artwork is reminiscent of hand-cut paper collages, further enhancing the traditional folk feeling of the game.  As far as gameplay goes, it mainly involves circling through a layered snowy landscape in search of puzzles and clues. As you advance the plot, new paths open up and new interactables appear. The key is figuring out which puzzles you can solve right away, and which you will need to come back to later after you have more information. Backtracking is a key component of the game, but the map is small enough that it never feels like a slog.  The built-in hint system is useful in guiding you through the main plot if you are stuck. It contains a progressive series of hints for each chapter, with the first hint being an extremely vague nudge in the right direction, and the last hint being a blatant spoiler. Players can control which hints are revealed and which remain hidden, so you only ever get as much information as you need.  Something I didn't realize on my first playthrough: Some puzzles require keyboard interaction, some puzzles require the mouse, some require a combination of keyboard and mouse. If you are stuck, it might be because you didn't realize you could click and drag an object to move it, or click and hold an item to carry it.  Some of the achievements are tricky to get, but between the game itself and the achievement descriptions, you should eventually be able to figure them all out.   While this game will likely leave you feeling depressed due to its tragic thematic elements, it is still an amazing little gem, and I would give it an overall rating of 9/10.

If Twin Peaks had been set in late-19th-century Sweden, it might have resembled Year Walk. Add in a distinctive art style, some clever (but not too challenging) puzzles, and a few jump scares -- we end up playing, excuse me, a damn fine cup of coff... adventure game.  Find a way to open the box.

WOW!  If you enjoy a good ol' mind **** then this is for you. By now you would have guessed that when it is over... It ain't over.   That is the part worth waiting for... Read the Journal... Open the box

6/10 in my opinion. Got it as part of a Humble Bundle - wouldn't pay full price but if you're looking to kill an hour, it's not a bad time.  Pros: -Art is unique -Cool atmosphere, spooky without being overly so -Folklore is interesting -Puzzles are somewhat intuitive if you half pay attention  Cons: -Needless jump-scares (I dislike them anyway) -Won't spoil the ending but it was pretty disatisfying to me -Puzzles really are too easy most of the time. -Short. Even taking my time it took me less than an hour and there's an achievement to finish in less than 20 minutes which having played it once I imagine would be quite easy.
Simogo, you are responsible for toast going on the dirty carpet (IRL) due to a jumpscare. You should be ashamed of yourself.
This game was beautiful in every way.

The game was quite enjoyable, with a simple little tale told through great art and animation.  If you are a fan of puzzles and folklore, then this is the game for you, my only issue with the game is that I wish it was longer.  I thoroughly enjoyed the playthrough.

This is such a great game, I really have no complaints about it. Perhaps only that I wish there was more, because of how great it is. Folklore from around the world has to be one of my most favourite things to find in a game, and this game really includes it well. I would love to play more games that involve the folklore and tales. It's not an obviously scary game, it's that creeping scare that builds as you play through the story. You slowly start to feel that paranoid itch that needs scratching, that feeling that something is wrong but you can't place it until something happens. It's beautiful and haunting in it's own way, and I can honestly say that I haven't enjoyed a game as much as this in quite awhile.
Intriguing and beatifull.
Wasn't my kind of game. It was interesting, and visually pretty. But I wouldn't recommend it to most of my friends...

Year Walk is a beautiful, unique experience, and despite its length, it is well worth the price. While this is considered a horror game, its primary draw is its clever puzzles and deceptively quaint and calming atmosphere that seem to take some inspiration from Tim Burton films. The sound design is excellent; both the music and sound effects are extremely crisp and know exactly when to go all out and when to draw back. There are even some music-based puzzles that will rely on your sense of pitch to be able to solve. However, most of the game is very quiet, with little to no music in many sections (though what music is there is quite well done), and only the eerily realistic sound of footsteps crruching in the thick snow will accompany you.  One of the key selling points of the game is its focus on Swedish folklore, which is told through a companion app (included in the Steam version) and, while it is not necessary to read, I highly recommend going through it so you will know about the different creatures you will encounter on your journey. I found myself fascinated with the folklore itself, and some of the legends are truly frightening. However, the horror elements are mostly intermittent and not exceptionally scary (most of the 'scary' parts I would classify more as unnerving than outright terrifying), I think this game is perfect for anyone who is new to horror games and will do a good job easing you into the genre.  However, despite my glowing recommendation, I would not recommend playing it on PC if you can get it for another device. This game was originally developed to be played on mobile devices, and while the cursor is perfectly functional, it feels a bit clunky and does not have the same seamless feel of dragging across the screen as using your finger. I would say the ideal version of the game would be the Wii U version, as it has the touch controls of the mobile version, the convenince of having the companion act on the GamePad, and is presented on a large TV to let you truly soak in the visuals. However, if you don't want to play on mobile and/or don't have a Wii U, you experience will not be significantly hampered if you choose to play it on PC. Highly recommend,

Entertaining game. Puzzle and some disturbing horror while staying true to (old) swedish folklore. Great atmosphere, love the art and music. Is best enjoyed with a pair of good headphones and a dark room.  It's about 1 hour at max to play through. Limited replayability.  Would recommend  Definitely worth 6 euros.
I could've saved her.

Hmm so what i loved about Year walk was the art sound and story telling of the game. im not usually one for point and click type games but i honestly loved it it was so trippy, and a little scary at times. probs one of my favorite games on the list check it out!!!!

The experience is short, but very poignant. Absolutely recommend this to the skeptical, assuming story is what draws you. It is cryptic, filled with mystery and without spoiling I have to direct to this: Just try it. I look forward to watching friends play through the same mystery. Otherwise, I can't say it has much of a replay value (or does it, winky face).
Magical and sometimes scary walk through the nordic mythology. Beware false ending!

Really cool game. It's pretty short and gameplay falls kind of flat, but the brilliant artistic style conveys an incredible atmosphere. While the game is, due to its 2D nature, not especially scary, it gave me severe goosebumps for the whole 90 minutes I was playing it. There's something really fascinating about the baffling story Year Walk has to tell.

Creepy, mysterious and beautifully presented, Year Walk is a horror adventure game unlike anything I've ever played. With puzzles that rarely frustrate and a uniquely eerie atmosphere bolstered by strong writing, it's an easy choice for adventure fans.
Really beautiful and atmospheric game. Anyone with an interest in Scandavian folklore would love this. A few good scares, too!
Obscure and surreal atmosphere, chills all the way through and a bit of a twist in the end.
Very atmospheric and beautifull puzzle game.

A very short game, very tightly packed with eery. Not exactly a horror, it leaves you rather sad than terrified. A walk through a forest, a journey through the brutal world of pagan mythology — not the one with epic gods' battles, but grassroots mythology with those things lurking in forests, wisps over marshes dead babies left in the woods. Some puzzles are easy, but some would require you to think outside the box. Overall, a creepy experience to remember.
Very cool & scary, was afraid to enter areas because of the scares. The game is very short, took me two hours to complete. If you see it on sale its worth picking up
10/10 would recommend uwu
A short but so worth it game. Keeps you thinking, when you finish the game it is really interesting to read the hidden journal.
Very beautiful yet pretty freaky game,  Full recommendations.   Some jump scares felt a bit unnecessary  but the overall feeling of the game was  thrillingly delightful.

Completely surpassed my expectations. Year Walk is a very smart game. It's a shame that so much of the plot exists only within the lengthy epilogue text, but that can be forgiven when that plot is so clever and interesting.  Also, awesome art style, and OH MY GOD THAT SOUNDTRACK. Best end-credits song since Still Alive.  My one major complaint is how often the game takes control away from the player. Every time an elaborate animation begins, you're forced to stare at it at the dev's intended angle. One particularly irritating example is when a character who you have to follow performs their walking-forward-animation, and you're prevented from moving while the camera points straight at the spectacle, temporarily rendering you unable to continue following the character. Very jarring and annoying.  But apart from that, Year Walk is delightful. Buy it. Don't you dare use a walkthrough.

A very short game, but an interesting way to introduce folklore into a game. Atmospheric and little bit creepy, but not scary. The game is mostly about deciphering a set of clues that allow you to solve puzzles as the game progresses. You must play the game at least twice to get everything and learn the whole story. There is supposedly a third ending but I couldn't figure out how to find it. A cool little brain teaser that has me wanting to pick up a book on Scandanavian folkore.
a game that is unique, creepy as hell and creative <3

Was not quite sure what to expect from this game. The reviews were good and it seemed pretty interesting so I figured what the hay. It didn't take very long before I was immersed in the game, and did a number of year walks. Although it's not a very long game, the story itself is intriguing and I find myself still thinking about it. Gotta go year walk now. Byyyye.
Dark, creepy, great story, wonderful music and graphics. Absolutely loved it!
A great game to play at midnight. Turn off all the lights and turn up the speakers.

I was expecting different things from the game at first but when i played for 3 hours long i became addicted to it.I really enjoyed playing it but i cant complete it cause of the part at the church where you turn around the church different times like i found how many times to go but it diidnt work but thats all but if i were t rate the game i would rate it a 8/10 cause i really loved it.:) hopefully you found this helpful.
The story begins when the game ends. I opened the box and saw the knife. This is the only thing I can do to save you.
Spooky as ♥♥♥♥ mang. Favorite atmosphere of any game, so quiet and beautiful
They should really put horror somewhere in the description. I'm just trying to save some undies of potential buyers.
Amazing game! Great challenging puzzles, haunting creatures and atmosphere, marvelous story, and 2 AMAZING ENDINGS!   Warbing! YOU WILL PROBABLY HAVE TO USE A WALkTHROUGH!  quack :acduck: quack

the story line cannot be comprhended in words. all i can say is that its the best ive encountered. but the gameplay is extremely simple! there is only eight controls! it is explorative and gets scary! but think about how Sweden actually believes these creatures exist! so it has spiritual value. this game is simply a work of art! this game deserves a ten out of ten all round.
Pretty dark adventure-like game. Lots of mood with an interesting story. Definitely play it twice.

A short but very atmospheric walking sim (yes, similar to the point&clicks - but a first person walk with arrow or wasd keys). For sure, it has a great creep factor but not terrifyingly so, otherwise I might not have been able to play. What I really loved most (other than the sound of the snow crunching under foot and great music) was the context of 19th century Swedish folklore. And I think if you have an interest in folklore, you would value this experience. I loved reading the encyclopedia which has spurred my own library search to read Swedish fairytales and folklore. I also loved the journal you acquire after the first playthrough. Which deepens the story leaving me at the end feeling as though I'd finished a good creepy read. Great stuff. Hard game? No. Enjoyable? Yes.
Such a fantastic game. Great concept and an awesome art style to go with it.
Great atmosphere, interesting hints of Norse folklore. Beautifully crafted in both design and sounds. Don't miss this little gem of a puzzle game

Pros: -Excellent atmosphere -Able to emotionally affect you -Interesting concept -Once it grabs you, it holds you until the end (I beat it in one play-through)  Cons: -Story may not seem completely cohesive, once you've hit the true, final ending -Movement is a little funny -A bit of backtracking  Worth a play. Especially for the price.
I really think there should be more games like this. I absolutely loved it, and it represents the folklore in a very interesting way. Well worth the price, it's one of my all time favourite games.

An amazing game, with a creepy feel for sure! It has such an amazing story and puzzle solving, I just couldnt get enough of it! I beat the game in only a day, but its a haunting game that you think about whenever you hear the name, that leaves an aftertaste in your mouth, that makes you want more. I play it again and again once in a while and cant wait to play it on new year's.  This game will never leave you disappointed. I was on the edge of my seat, holding my breath and still at certain parts, I would jump like a ♥♥♥♥♥.  11/10
Amazing Game, great portrayal of Swedish folktale, and super atmospheric and eerie. Overall just a really beautiful game
nothing this full of dead children should be this pretty, 10/10

I love love love Scandinavian folklore, and I'd only vaguely heard of year-walking until I played the game. The amount of detail put into it was thrilling and everything-- the music, the visuals, the details-- brought it together really well. I would definitely recommend this to lovers of creepy point-and-click games. Just remember to write stuff down!!

[Game originally played on iOS]  If you're looking for a review to determine if this is a game worthy of your time, I'll cut you the search: yes, it absolutely is. I'll get more into my thoughts on the game itself below.  However.  I can't believe I'm saying this, but if you own an iPhone or iPad, get that version instead. There are a lot of puzzles that make a lot more sense and that are a lot more clever with touch controls. There's no reason not to at least pick that version up first. The visuals are identical, it's a few bucks cheaper, and the controls are arguably better when actually using your fingers to swipe across the environment.  As for the game itself, it's a stellar game. For such a short runtime, Year Walk shows an interesting world and builds a genuinely fascinating and creepy atmosphere. The visuals are absolutely gorgeous and really compliment that atmosphere. The story is also really clever and doesn't overstay it's welcome. Much like the original Portal, it's short, sweet, and gets it's point across with no distractions. All killer, no filler.  Absolutely pick this game up if it looks up your alley. Again, I'd urge you to try the iOS version first if you have that option available to you. If not, the PC release is absolutely fine, with only sometimes fiddly controls and a few surprises neutered in the process. I highly recommend Year Walk.
It was interesting but very short. I wish I had played on a tablet, as some of the puzzles are designed for swiping and it's hard to emulate with a mouse. I'd only recommend if it's on sale.

Very interesting and unique game with a dark and slightly creepy atmosphere. I enjoyed it a lot. The encyclopedia tells some interesting tales which will help make your Year Walk easier and on top of that, you have access to hints to point you in the right direction. The first time you finish the game, it isn't exactly over yet. You are given a clue to discover a secret, which will lead to a lot more information and the actual end of the game. The achievements are small puzzles themselves, as you don't get them for simply completing the Year Walk; you need to do things in a certain order, not use hints, etc. It's definitely worth another walk to get these done and it won't take long if you paid attention and/or took notes during your first walk.

Describing this game as 'atmospheric' is an understatement. I love the attention to detail - the soft crunch of snow with each step you take and the complete isolation of the wintery woods. The blending of mythos and mystery is carefully considered. It's a shorter game, but I didn't find it lacking or feel like the price was unreasonable. It's as much of an artful experience as it is a game.

This is my review of Year Walk.  Well, what a game that was. Or maybe it shouldn't be called a game. Instead, an experience in solitude. I had owned this game for over a year before finally playing it, and I can't lie, I’m kind of annoyed I waited that long. Me and My Associate decided to go through all of the games that I have not played in my Steam Library and this was one of them.   I had no idea what to expect when we started up the game. I was pleasantly surprised by how much we enjoyed it. This game is an Exploration Puzzle game with odd navigation controls. You soon get used to it and the game becomes a blast. You navigate across 2D planes in first person and hop between layers of the world. First of all, the sound design is peng. The crispyty crunch of the noise of snow under your feet is a very nice and subtle choice and puts you right in the Snowy Swedish Wilderness. The art style was reminiscent of 'Fosters Home for Imaginary Kids' and really suited the shifting tone of Wonder and Dread (Not the Judge). The story is difficult to explain and should be experienced first-hand with all the pieces of the puzzle aligning to make a beautiful mosaic of Swedish folklore. I would valiantly recommend giving this Modern Masterpiece a couple of hours of your time.  Remember Dear Readers, You heard it here first. Off the record, On the QT, and very Hush-Hush.

For the longest time I put off buying Year Walk since the price tag versus the average amount of hours reviewers played tended to scare me away. I usually like investing in things I know I'll get a good amount of time out of, and I felt that I could just as easily wait for a sale to get something that I'd spend more time on for around the same price. I know this is incredibly moronic tact to take with games, but I've been burned more often than not on shorter 'experiences' to come to have that reservation.   Having bought and completed Year Walk, I can honestly say I wish I pulled the trigger on the game sooner.  The folklore the game is based on is interesting and a bit unsettling, leading to simple, yet effective scares that managed to stick with me. Wrapped around this is a pretty well done story, that even with accidentally getting spoiled on some of the details, I came away impressed with. While I wouldn't say the puzzles are anything too special, combined with an atmospheric soundtrack and the game's 2.5D first person presentation, they were enough to get me to want to to keep going.  Admittedly, Year Walk might not be everyone's cup of tea. Regardless, if you're looking for something different, I highly recommend taking a chance on it.
A great pick for anyone interested in less explored aspects of Nordic folklore. Not a lot of action, but a great sense of discovery and really solid atmosphere.
Stay past the credits!!!!!!!!!!!!!! The game isn't over yet.

Playing through this game was a very interesting experience to say the least. The story was captivating while the visual art/music kept you immersed in the world and folklore. Make sure to play through twice to get the real ending!
